MRI scan of left knee to assess meniscal tear

text.div: Knee pain and swelling after football match injury

20-year-old Saudi university student and football player injured left knee during match 2 days ago. Planted foot and twisted while being tackled. Immediate pain and swelling. Able to walk but with limp. Pain rated 6/10, worse with twisting movements. No locking but feels unstable. Previously healthy with no knee problems. Regular football training 5 days/week. No previous significant injuries. Concerned about impact on university football scholarship.

Left knee visibly swollen with moderate effusion. Tenderness along medial joint line. Positive McMurray test suggesting meniscal tear. Lachman and drawer tests negative (stable ACL). Range of motion limited - flexion to 90 degrees due to pain and swelling. Antalgic gait present. Pain score 6/10.

Assessment: Probable medial meniscus tear, left knee, secondary to sports injury. Stable knee ligaments. Moderate knee effusion limiting function.

Plan:

  1. MRI left knee scheduled for July 25th to confirm meniscal tear extent
  2. Rest from football activities - no pivoting sports until cleared
  3. RICE protocol (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation) - ice 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours
  4. Ibuprofen 400mg TID with food for pain and inflammation
  5. Physiotherapy referral for strengthening and mobility exercises
  6. Knee brace during activities for support and stability
  7. Sports injury prevention education and RICE protocol training
  8. Follow-up in 1 week with MRI results to discuss treatment options
  9. Gradual return to sports protocol once cleared by physiotherapy

coding.display: History of family member diseases Narrative

text.div: Family history relevant to musculoskeletal health and sports injuries. Father was former professional football player who had multiple knee surgeries and developed early arthritis. Paternal uncle has chronic back pain from construction work. Older brother is also athletic (basketball) with history of ankle injuries but no knee problems. Mother has osteoporosis but no significant joint issues. Family demonstrates pattern of joint problems related to high physical activity levels and occupational factors.

note.text: Former professional football player (1995-2010) who developed early osteoarthritis in both knees following multiple injuries and surgeries. Had 3 arthroscopic procedures and 1 ACL reconstruction. Currently manages with physiotherapy, weight control, and occasional cortisone injections.
Multiple meniscal tears throughout football career requiring 2 partial meniscectomies. These contributed to development of secondary osteoarthritis.

Chronic lower back pain from 25 years of heavy construction work. Has disc degeneration at L4-L5 level. Manages with physiotherapy, ergonomic modifications, and occasional pain medication. Unable to perform heavy lifting.
Basketball player who has had 2 significant ankle sprains requiring physiotherapy and rehabilitation. No knee injuries. Currently plays university-level basketball with ankle taping for support.

Early-onset osteoporosis diagnosed at age 42 following DEXA scan. Likely related to calcium deficiency and limited sun exposure. Takes calcium and vitamin D supplements with regular bone density monitoring. No fractures to date.
